text: What's up everybody? Eric here. Welcome back to the outlier podcast. I got my friends from Duneberg back on my favorite green chicken. So it's been about a quarter since we've spoken last and maybe like a lot has happened also not. I guess there's always a lot happening, but I thought it would be cool to start with looking back at 2023 and from your purview as a whole, two things. First, what stood out to you in two? How did things progress against expectations for you? Great questions. And first of all, great to be back with you. I always enjoy our conversations and it's going to be a fun one today. The thing that jumps out to us in 2023, first and foremost, is the lack of a recession in the US. I think the consensus view heading into the year was the Fed couldn't raise rates at the speed with which they were attending to without destroying the economy. And the big aha for us during the year is neither of those materialized. The US kept producing record-breaking month after record-breaking month of oil and NGLs and natural gas and even exported a record volume or value of coal. And also the US did not slip into a recession. And as an analyst, when you get something raw, what matters most is what you learn from it. And the difference between an analyst and an advocate is an analyst seeks to understand, as opposed to an advocate seeks to be proven right. And we pride ourselves on trying our best to be analyst. Look every time you make a call, you'd like to be right. But when you're not right, that's a really amazing opportunity to learn. And one of the rare big sort of aha's in the second half of 2023 was connecting those two dots. The US did not go into recession precisely because it is a hydrocarbon-producing powerhouse.
